eadheader.eadid: PUBLIC "-//American Philosophical Society LIBRARY//TEXT(US::PAAV::B J92:: Horace Freeland Judson Collection)//EN" "judson.xml"

titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by rsc
titlestmt.sponsor: Support for processing the Judson Papers was provided by a grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-09-13T19:35-0400

did.abstract: Between 1968 and 1978, the historian of science Horace Freeland Judson conducted extensive oral history interviews with biochemists and molecular biologists relating to the development of their field. The correspondence, transcripts of interviews, and taped interviews that comprise the Judson collection formed the research material used by Judson in his book, The Eighth Day of Creation (New York, 1979). Permission to quote must be obtained from Dr. Judson and access to some files is restricted.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: After a varied career as graduate student, researcher for the American O.M.G. in Berlin, editor, advertising copywriter, and journalist, Judson found his metier as a chronicler and historian of science. His masterpiece, The Eighth Day of Creation, established him in 1979 as peerless in the use of taped interviews, usually repeated and revised several times, as a basis of probing the actual genesis of discovery and the history of ideas in modern science.

The Horace Judson Papers (1968-1978) contain correspondence and transcripts of interviews with molecular biologists concerning the development of their field. Judson used this research as the basis for a series of articles published as "Annals of Science: DNA" in The New Yorker issues of November 27, December 4, and December 11, 1978, and later compiled them in book-length form as The Eighth Day of Creation: Makers of the Revolution in Biology (New York: Simon & Schuster, 1979).

Many, but not all of Judson's interviews are transcribed in full or entirely verbatim. In some cases, however, the transcripts are sketchy, and might more properly be called notes on a conversation. In case of doubt, the recordings alone (Rec. 113A) are the actual record, and reference should be made to them. It should be stressed that these transcripts and notes were made by Judson and may ignore background discussions that Judson had no need to refer to later, but that others may find of value.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Judson Papers are comprised of 52 tape recorded oral history interviews and 1 linear foot of transcripts, 1968-1978, arranged alphabetically by the name of the interviewee. The collection forms a major resource for study of the early history of molecular biology and the development of nucleic acid.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: This collection is available for scholarly use at the American Philosophical Society Library, only with the prior written permission of Horace Judson. Judson may be reached through the APS Manuscripts Department.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: The files containing material regarding Matthew Meselson, Maurice Wilkinson, and women at King's College are closed indefinitely to researchers.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Cite as: Horace Freeland Judson Collection, American Philosophical Society.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The Horace Judson Papers were donated by Horace Judson in December 1978 (accession number 1979-70ms).

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: The collection has been microfilmed in its entirety (Film 1402). The microfilm is arranged in a main alphabetical sequence, which is followed by interviews with scientists at the Cavendish Laboratory (Bragg, Kendrew, Barnett, Blow, Huxley, Phillips, and Klug), with scientists and others associated with the Pasteur Institute Laboratory (Jacob, Monod, Gros, Lwoff, Ephrussi, Cohen, Wollman, Perrin, Noufflard, Ullman, Jungelson, and members of Monod's family), with Max Perutz, and finally, by interviews with Brenner and Crick.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials note
separatedmaterial.p: The audiotapes have been removed for storage to the Audiovisal Collections (Rec. 113a).

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids note
otherfindaid.p: The Judson Collection is also described in Bentley Glass, Guide to the Genetics Collections of the American Philosophical Society (Philadelphia: APS, 1988).

odd.head: Genetics note
odd.p: This collection contains materials which relate to the history of genetics.
